Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Scalable Routing in 3D Wireless Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: There have been increasing interests in deploying wireless sensors in three-dimensional (3D) space for such applications as underwater reconnaissance and atmospheric monitoring. An individual sensor is highly resource-constrained, with extremely limited computing, storage, and communication capacities. To network a large number of such sensor nodes is challenging. Particularly, compared with its 2D counterpart, the scalability problem is greatly exacerbated in a 3D sensor network due to dramatically increased sensor quantity in order to cover a 3D space. The state-of-the-art routing algorithms that offer the best scalability cannot be applied in 3D directly. As a matter of fact, it has been proven that there is no deterministic algorithm that can guarantee delivery based on local information only in a 3D network. This project centers on scalable routing protocols for wireless sensor networks deployed in a 3D space. A key strategy of this research is to preprocess the global network information via a distributed algorithm, such that a sensor only needs to store a minimum amount of information to make correct and efficient local routing decisions, thus achieving scalable routing. To this end, geometric theories and tools are exploited to develop practical routing algorithms that provide guaranteed delivery, require small bounded storage, and are based on local computation only. Three approaches, namely, routing-via-backbone, routing-in-3D-virtual-coordinates, and segment-and-route, are developed. Furthermore, a testbed will be established for experimental exploration and evaluation of 3D routing. The 3D sensor network technologies developed in this project will benefit several fields ranging from biological research to environmental monitoring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There have been increasing interests in deploying wireless sensors in three-dimensional (3D) space for such applications as underwater reconnaissance and atmospheric monitoring. An individual sensor is highly resource-constrained, with extremely limited computing, storage, and communication capacities. To network a large number of such sensor nodes is challenging. Particularly, compared with its 2D counterpart, the scalability problem is greatly exacerbated in a 3D sensor network due to dramatically increased sensor quantity in order to cover a 3D space. The state-of-the-art routing algorithms that offer the best scalability cannot be applied in 3D directly. As a matter of fact, it has been proven that there is no deterministic algorithm that can guarantee delivery based on local information only in a 3D network. This project intends to understand, analyze, design, implement, evaluate, and prototype scalable routing protocols for wireless sensor networks deployed in a 3D space. A key strategy of the proposed solutions is to preprocess the global network information via a distributed algorithm, such that a sensor only needs to store a minimum amount of information to make correct and efficient local routing decisions, thus achieving scalable routing. To this end, geometric theories and tools are exploited to develop practical routing algorithms that provide guaranteed delivery, require small bounded storage, and are based on local computation only. Three approaches, namely, routing-via-backbone, routing-in-3D-virtual-coordinates, and segment-and-route, are proposed. Furthermore, a testbed is established for experimental exploration and evaluation of 3D routing. This is the first such research project that systematically studies the problem of routing in 3D wireless sensor networks. The PIs investigate the fundamental new challenges and develop novel, practical, and theoretically­ proven solutions to support efficient routing in 3D wireless sensor networks. The findings in the this project are presented in several high­-profile conferences and journals, including ACM MobiHoc, IEEE INFOCOM, IEEE ICDCS, and IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking. 

This project has a broad impact on multi-disciplinary research and education. The 3D sensor network technologies developed in this project benefits several fields ranging from biological research to environmental monitoring. The testbed established in this project provides students with hands-on experience, which has been shown to be an important factor in stimulating students interest and sharpening their scientific reasoning and problem solving skills. The PIs actively incorporate general sensor network technologies, geometric theories, and particular research findings from this project into related courses, in order to popularize these new wireless technologies and attract more students into this emerging area. Particularly, four talented graduate students at the Ph.D. level are recruited for participating in the proposed research, rewarding all of us who are striving to cultivate the next generation of elite scientists and educators. Moreover, the PIs are committed to the mission of developing and improving the participation of underrepresented groups. Two undergraduate students from minority groups work with the PIs on the development of a sensor platform suitable for 3D deployment. The PIs further partner with existing university recruitment mechanisms, such as the McNair Scholars and the LS-LAMP programs to substantially increase the number of underrepresented students completing degrees in science, engineering, and technology.

  • This is the first work that realizes truly deterministic greedy routing with constant-bounded storage and computation in 3D wireless sensor networks. We propose a distributed algorithm to realize volumetric harmonic mapping of the 3D sensor network, where greedy routing is guaranteed to succeed.
